frameDefinitions: An Agent displays a Characteristic of a Standard in his or her own way of behaving.
This frame concerns a specific subset of Instances of a Type which are evaluated in terms of their similarity to a conceptual prototype of the Type.
An Agent affects a Patient in such a way that the Patient (or some Subregion of the Patient) ends up in a non-canonical state.
An Entity is evaluated for whether or not it belongs to a particular Reference_category in a context where its category membership is doubtful.
This frame describes a particular instance of an event.
A New filler occupies a Role or serves a Function after the Old filler ceases to occupy the position.
frameExamples: I guessed he was trying to <t>imitate</t> the movements of a skier

It can be hard to get your money back after discovering you've bought a <t>bogus</t>
autograph for hundreds or thousands of dollars!
These next two days will be the last two <t>times</t> that I'm here.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person that borrows a <fen>Characteristic</fen> behavior from a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Characteristic</fen> is a behavior or property that the <fen>Standard</fen> possesses and which the <fen>Agent</fen> adopts in his or her own behavior.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the entity that exhibits a certain <fen>Characteristic</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> models their own behavior on.
The time at which the imitation occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> imitates some entity which acts as a <fen>Standard</fen>.
A thing or episode that is considered exemplary of a certain <fen>Type</fen>.
The category of things or events from which an <fen>Instance</fen> is picked out.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs the intentional action that results in the damage to the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The entity which is affected by the <fen>Agent</fen> so that it is damaged.
An event which leads to the damage of the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> damages the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the location of the scene where a <fen>Agent</fen> damages a <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Entity</fen> that is being evaluated in terms of whether it is an instance of the <fen>Reference_category</fen>.
The type relative to which the <fen>Entity</fen> is evaluated.
The particular <fen>Instance</fen> of a given event. All LUs in this frame incorporate this Frame Element.
The event that occurred in one or more instances.
The new filler of the <fen>Role</fen> that was previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen> filler.
The category that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities fit into as a result of the <fen>Function</fen> they serve.
The (generally desirable) state of affairs that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities are involved in bringing about.
The entity that occupied the <fen>Role</fen> or served the <fen>Function</fen> before the <fen>New</fen> filler.
The time at which the <fen>New</fen> takes up the <fen>Role</fen> previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Mimic Snotlings do n't really think for themselves, <fex>they</fex> merely mimic the actions of Orcs and Goblins around them.
The singer says Gwen has copied <fex>her</fex> in many different ways.
<fex>The crash</fex> dented my car pretty bad.
<fex>The bomb found at the US Embassy in Berlin</fex> was fake.
He dumped trash for the last <fex>time</fex>.
The traditional thatched roof has often been replaced <fex>by corrugated galvanized iron</fex>.
What gas replaced Hydrogen <fex>as a safer medium for use in balloons</fex> on account it does not burn?
Oil and gas replaced coal <fex>in heating homes, in industry, and in transportation</fex>.
The electron was discovered and <fex>electricity</fex> replaced gas lamps.
When electricity replaced oil <fex>in the early 1930's</fex>, the steady beam was replaced by a flashing light.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: A Brief Tour of Human Consciousness
"Mirror Neurons and the Great Leap Forward"
